text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Dear Superpath,

Recently, I experienced some pretty rapid and sudden career growth. I went from being a copywriter at an agency to an in-house campaigns lead at a rapidly-growing startup. It's a role I'd been chasing for a couple of years before I even landed the opportunity to interview for it.

I've been here for about 6 months now, and while my coworkers and lead are great and the company is healthy in terms of the working environment, I'm still waiting to stop feeling like I'm not cut out for management work. 
 
The truth is, I miss being an individual contributor. I get so much more satisfaction, pride and a sense of accomplishment from doing the deep work of SEO analysis, researching, interviewing, editing, writing and distribution than I do from crafting strategy and managing others. I dread conversations about further career growth because I can't shake off the conviction that I'm better cut out as an individual contributor. 

I guess my question is: has anyone found themselves in this spot? And what did you do about it? Did you take a step back into an IC role? Built up a freelancing gig? Sought coaching? 

Thank you!"

SInce you have writer's block, you want me to send you mine I just used for my last round of job interviews? It seemed to get a pretty good response.  I also used bullet points.

I structured it to touch on the job's opportunity obviously, but the main messaging was more of my values and why I would make a great teammate/contribution to the org rather than how qualified I am for the specific job. I guess more of a strategic narrative than a cover letter. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Going into management is not the only way to experience career growth. Trust your gut and do what you love. I know people who waited too long to listen to their own intuition and toiled away unhappily in management roles they hated. Many worry about being perceived as “taking a step backwards” in their career, but I don’t think doing what you love instead of what you don’t love is ever taking a step backwards. Careers are long. Maybe you’ll enjoy management more later in your career.

elements.text: Going into management is not the only way to experience career growth. Trust your gut and do what you love. I know people who waited too long to listen to their own intuition and toiled away unhappily in management roles they hated. Many worry about being perceived as “taking a step backwards” in their career, but I don’t think doing what you love instead of what you don’t love is ever taking a step backwards. Careers are long. Maybe you’ll enjoy management more later in your career.

text:
The move from IC to manager is often analogized as "from orchestra member to conductor" and I think it's a perfect.

Deep work is a luxury the further you rise up the ranks. And the tactical tasks that you found fulfilling before now must be delegated. It's a shocking reality for folks like you and me.

You've only been at it for six months, so it's unlikely you'll feel comfortable yet. Hell, I've been overseeing global content marketing operations, setting the strategy, and developing careers for a few years now and I still feel nostalgic for "simpler times" because, truth is,  motivating and training yourself is hard work — but it's a whole lot easier than helping someone else do it for you.

The TL;DR of this is: Management requires a very different skill set that, unfortunately, isn't often developed before someone gets the role. So a lot of what you're experiencing is a skills gap. If the gap is far too intimidating, sure you can go back to being an IC. But if you chased this dream for years, I encourage you to work on closing the gap. Here are ways I've done (and honestly am still doing) it:

• *Get a coach:* You brought this up and I couldn't recommend this more. When you have an objective outsider to share your vulnerabilities with, sometimes expressing your self-doubt is the only antidote you need. And if you need more than that, a coach will have a tool chest of strategies and tactics to help.
• *Adopt a "progress over perfection" mindset:* If you think back to your IC days, it's unlikely that you were as skilled towards the end when you first started. The same applies today as a manager. You're a novice now and will become an expert by acknowledging your limitations and chipping away at them. (note: I will come back later and link a question from Airtable's Margaret Jones' AMA about this)
• *Invest in a network to support you:* The good news is you're already doing this here! Similar to professional coaching, a circle of leaders outside your organization you can talk shop and bounce ideas off of is crucial. 
I also highly recommend reading Julie Zhuo's "The Making of a Manager: What to Do When Everyone Looks to You." It's one of the most refreshing reads on modern management I've ever read.

Final thought: If you're not afraid to break your anonymity, don't hesitate to DM me.

Good luck!

text: I haven't experienced this, but I have a friend who did and she basically made her narrative that she had to get the broad experience to realize what specialty she truly loves. She went from basically being the functional CMO of the marketing team to designing decks because she said how she often had to communicate her ideas to executives using that tool and she realized what a powerful tool it was. Blah, blah, whatever, she just wanted less responsibility and to be able to work in silence. :slightly_smiling_face: But people seemed to think it was cool. The specialization route may be something for you to consider.
